speaker: therapist
text: Hello, welcome. Please make yourself comfortable. I’m glad you decided to come in today. To start, could you share a bit about what brought you here and what you hope to work on regarding communication?

speaker: client
text: Thanks. Well, I’ve always struggled with speaking clearly, especially when I’m stressed. People often ask me to repeat myself, and in arguments with my partner, I just shut down. It’s frustrating.

speaker: therapist
text: I appreciate you sharing that. It sounds like it affects both everyday conversations and close relationships. When you say you ‘shut down,’ can you describe what happens physically or mentally in those moments?

speaker: client
text: My mind goes blank. I can feel my throat tighten, and even if I have things to say, they just don’t come out. Later, I get upset because I didn’t express what I needed to.

speaker: therapist
text: That’s a very clear description. What you’re experiencing is common with communication blocks, where emotion and speech production intersect. Have you ever tried any strategies to help in those moments?

speaker: client
text: I’ve tried to just push through, but it makes me stutter. Sometimes I write things down for my partner afterward, but it doesn’t feel the same as saying it in the moment.

speaker: therapist
text: Writing is actually a great alternative communication method—thank you for mentioning that. In our work together, we can explore a combination of approaches. One part would focus on speech mechanics—clarity, pacing—through speech-language pathology techniques. The other would address emotional and relational patterns using psychotherapy tools. How does that sound?

speaker: client
text: It sounds comprehensive. But can it help quickly? I’m worried about an upcoming family gathering where I’ll have to speak in front of everyone.

speaker: therapist
text: That’s a great practical concern. We can start with some immediate tools. For example, mindfulness exercises to reduce the physical tension you described, and a technique called ‘structured turn-taking’ you could practice with your partner before the event. Would you like to try a brief mindfulness exercise now?

speaker: client
text: Yes, that would be good.

speaker: therapist
text: Great. Let’s sit comfortably. Close your eyes if you’re comfortable. Just notice your breath for a moment... Now, bring your attention to your throat and jaw. Without trying to change anything, just notice any sensations there. If there’s tightness, imagine breathing into that space. We’re not trying to force relaxation, just bringing awareness. We can use this before or during a conversation to ground ourselves. Take another breath, and when you’re ready, open your eyes. How was that?

speaker: client
text: It felt a little easier. I could feel the tightness you mentioned, but focusing on it made it less overwhelming.

speaker: therapist
text: Excellent. That awareness is the first step toward gaining control. Now, for the relational part, you mentioned your partner. Would they be open to joining a session sometime? Involving close supports often helps in practicing new skills in a safe environment.

speaker: client
text: I think they would. They’ve said they want to help but don’t know how.

speaker: therapist
text: That’s a great starting point. We could work on active listening exercises and creating ‘communication contracts’—like agreeing to pause if someone feels overwhelmed. Before we finish, I’d like to get a sense of your goals. If therapy is successful a year from now, what would be different?

speaker: client
text: I’d like to speak without so much fear. To be able to disagree with my partner without freezing. And to not have to repeat myself all the time at work.

speaker: therapist
text: Those are very achievable goals. The path will involve the techniques we discussed: speech exercises for clarity, CBT and mindfulness for the anxiety, and relational practice for the partnership. We’ll move at your pace. How are you feeling about this plan?

speaker: client
text: Hopeful. And relieved to have a plan. I was worried it was just something I had to live with.

speaker: therapist
text: I’m glad to hear that. You don’t have to just live with it. We’ll work together on both the technical and emotional sides of communication. For next time, I’ll give you a simple exercise: practice the mindfulness of throat/jaw tension once a day, and if you feel comfortable, note one situation where communication felt slightly easier or harder. Does that work for you?

speaker: client
text: Yes, I can do that.

speaker: therapist
text: Wonderful. Thank you for your openness today. I look forward to our next session.
